This show might hurt a little or make you feel nostalgic for memories of your own. For an unlikely scenario, you feel as though it is very, very real. 
I expected Nana to be, the first 15 episodes in, a series where you live vicariously through the main character, Nana Komatsu, later known as Hachi. She meets a new cool and beautiful best friend, she's starting a new life in Tokyo in a cute apartment with a handsome boyfriend, friends all around, including getting to know some really attractive members of a famous band. Sounds great, right?
It's not all blown away by tragedy, it's shakenup by misunderstandings/lies, fear, love, career pursuits, and life in general, as the two girls are very different and live very separate lifestyles, and it becomes more apparent as the show goes on, causing some interesting rifts. Despite this, their friendship and caring for one another is one of the strongest aspects of the show, but it's not shoved down your throat in a 'FRIENDSHIP IS THE MOST IMPORTANT THING EVER!!!1' type way. Nana portrays realistic emotions that apply to any situation very straight and bittersweet, yet savory at the same time. 


The Story: 10/10. There are no loopholes. Everything has a purpose, every action is made understandable, and everything is well done. There are no filler episodes, which is saying a lot for a series with 47 episode slots to fill. It's far from boring, especially during the second half, where things escalate quickly. 


Characters: 9/10 How I WISH I could give this a 10 out of 10, as the characters are arguably the best part of the show. Hachi is more than just your ditzy, friendly, feminine young adult, she is also very considerate, yet struggles with her own selfishness, a trait she acknowledges but dislikes. Nana Osaki is not just a cool, punk, lead singer, she is just as, if not more, selfish than Hachi, and worries about depending on other people to the point where it hinders her relationships or makes her seem distant. The other main characters: Reira, Shin, Yasu, Ren, Nobu, Takumi... are very, VERY fleshed out and interesting, the minor characters: Misato, Junko, Kyosuke being just as much. The reason this has a 9/10 is because Naoki, a drummer in the band Trapnest, who appears regularly in the show and openings, has little to no character development. I get that he's not that important in comparison, but I would have liked him to have had a bigger role. 


Art: 9/10 It's Ai Yazawa. All of her designs are very pretty, appealing, modern, and fashionable, with punk edges Vivienne Westwood herself would be proud of, and lace. This has a nine out of ten, as this is a slice of life series, and there is very little room to be super experimental with the art, but all the lighting, scenery, and little details such as the accessories, are very tastefully done, and all the characters are easy on the eyes. 


Sound: 10/10 ANOTHER one of the best aspects of the show. Since Nana revolves not only around the two main girls, but two bands: Blast and Trapnest, the show has songs recorded by fictionalized versions of these two bands, and it is AWESOME. Blast's songs are punky and energetic, with a demure husky female voice. Trapnest's songs are pretty and poetic, with an angelic female lead voice with a slight rock edge. Personally, I prefer Trapnest's sound and voice to Blast's, BUT that's like saying you prefer cookies to cupcakes. Both are absolutely savory and you'll take them if available.


Enjoyment: 9/10. I watched this show when I was going through relationship troubles on my own. It was simultaneously a big mistake and a much needed detox, as I cried a few times, and at one point got so emotional that I could not finish it until a year later. When I did, I took a while to take everything in, as that ending really got to me. It's not sad, per se, just very true. It's a 9/10 because parts of it made me sad, and while I personally enjoy shows that make me sad and think a lot, I realize some might not. I -did- very much enjoy it though, and it has a heavy rewatch value to relive some of those moments the show has to offer. 


Overall, I cannot recommend Nana enough, even if you typically do not do slice of life/shoujo. You are not too manly for Nana, unless you eat feelings and rocks for breakfast. I feel as though not enough people have seen it, and it perplexes me as it is delicacy. Nana is an experience.

What is Nana? 
What is the story about?
(Warning: the following review contains some spoilers, because that’s really the only way you can review something like this.)
I had to ask myself what this anime was about several times per episode. I had to try to find some ultimate conclusion, because this was such a good anime, but it never seemed to want to give me an answer.
And finally, on the last episode, when the final song played, I realized what this was all about: hopelessness. In every sense of the world, the story of Nana and Nana is a tragedy. There is no happy ending foranyone, not really. There’s nothing to feel good about in the slightest. Every single character save for one (Yasu) ends up being a terrible person, full of personality flaws and the impressive ability to make only bad decisions. If you want the basic premise of the story, read the other reviews, because what I want to say is that these characters all end up basically unhappy or on the precipice of unhappiness, hanging by a thread and miring in a mud pit of depression and lost hope. The best example of this is Hachi (Valley girl Nana who was given that nickname for practicality) – her story is pretty much the most depressing story ever. She’s a selfish, pathetic excuse for a woman who cares about nothing in the world except herself. I had to ask myself why the other characters even liked her. She was just annoying and by the end of the anime, you’ll find yourself open-mouthed and completely aghast because you just can’t believe her story actually ends the way it does. I won’t say more, but it’s completely pathetic.


But, you know what? That was the intention. That’s who Hachi is and the anime doesn’t try to make excuses for her. This wasn’t supposed to be a happy story. Unfortunately, through the first 20 episodes, you find so much hope and great things, that it’s kind of a let-down afterwards, because it sinks into the hole of depression that it never digs itself out from. But the original intention of this was to tell the shabby story of these two women and what happened to them. In a sense, it was supposed to display realism at its ugliest – a godless, soulless world and the creators of this anime accomplished what they set out to do. Friendships are chance, marriage is always a mistake and love is an illusion – people are only out to serve themselves, but every now and then, you need someone to support the burden you carry in life, and that is what people call relationships. They serve no other purpose.


Now, I’m not a believer in this ideology personally, but still, what they set out to do, they finished with style. Nana has a unique fashion and voice all its own and it leads to several powerful episodes that would have been hard to pull off otherwise. The voice acting and music is second to none, full of emotion and while the crying scenes aren’t exactly few and far between, they’re well done and you usually can connect with them on some level.


So, what did I get from Nana in the end? Well, I had to analyze my own interpretation of love and romance and test it to see if it’s what I believed. When an anime can make you really think and care at the same time, it’s truly something special. Nana is definitely special and I would recommend it to anyone. I didn’t enjoy the ending and the first 23 episodes are better than the last 24 by far, but what can you do? Also, I have to warn anyone who watches this that the two main characters don’t actually talk to each other for the last fourth of the series, which was a huge letdown. I mean, how can you do that? Plus Hachi’s story completely loses steam while Punk Rock Nana’s story takes center stage. For the first 3 fourths of the story, their stories intertwine, but it just falls flat in the end to where Hachi become completely irrelevant, which is too bad. The ending was a failure on most levels as a result, I’m sorry to report. It left a seriously bad cliffhanger with obvious intentions of a second season that was hardly a representation of the whole of the series. It was like 46 plus 1. As close to epic fail as you can get.


I still thoroughly enjoyed this anime though, if only to satisfy my dark side and need to plunge into darkness now and again. (On a personal note, I hate Takumi and I constantly hoped he would die. *Sigh* unfortunately, he does not.) But I will definitely need a fresh dose of something uplifting like Nodame Cantabile to bring me back from the depths. In the end, I just thought it was too bad that this anime just refused to allow for some hope. 


I prefer a world where hope exists.

Behold, the king (or queen?) of all shoujo anime, Nana.
The shoujo genre is one that can evoke a certain degree of condescension for some people. The sudden sparkly backgrounds, contrived romantic situations, bishies on top of bishies, and unnecessary melodrama. In short, it can showcase a somewhat "idealized" version of youthful romance. 
But even if you're guilty of having these thoughts, I implore you not to ignore this specific show because of the "shoujo" tag. Because unlike other shows in the genre, Nana takes on a more grounded, realistic approach. Things are not perfect. The characters have flaws. They makes mistakes and poor decisions, theirrelationships are neither simple nor ideal, and things don't always work out how you think they should.


The setup is simple. Two strangers, both named Nana, end up as roommates in Tokyo. They're almost complete opposites and make their trip to the big city for different reasons as well. "Rocker Nana" as I call her, to make it big in the music industry, and the other Nana, "Hachi", to reunite with her boyfriend. Needless to say, and without spoiling anything, it's a bumpy road on both fronts, as both Nana's lives slowly become intertwined.


On that note, the relationship between the Nana is something I found particularly interesting. It's not the usual "two opposites butt heads until enough bonding moments occur to bring them together and form a strong friendship" trope. It's a bit more complicated than that. Their relationship is far from perfect. There's jealousy, possessiveness, and unspoken feelings. In ways, it almost feels like a romantic relationship without the actual romance. It was a dynamic that surprised me.


As far as the other relationships go, as expected there is a fair amount of drama and romance. Sure, at times it can get just a little "soap opera-y", but never to the point past suspension of disbelief. And that's the one thing that strikes me about Nana. Even with all the drama, the characters and story are presented in a real, sometimes raw, manner that is so difficult to accomplish in anime and deserves its due praise.


As expected from an anime with a such a focus on music, the soundtrack is exceptional. Every once in awhile the first opening "Rose" pops into my head.


The art is above average, but also relatively standard shoujo fare. Most people are pretty tall, really skinny, and the male love interests are often as pretty as some of the female characters.


I guess the biggest gripe would be the fact we still haven't gotten an ending, as the original manga is on indefinite hiatus as the author's health took a decline. Let's hope for healthy days ahead for Ai Yazawa, regardless of whether Nana is continued. She gave us a really compelling story and set of characters and I hope she's doing ok.


TL;DR: Whether you enjoy shoujo or not, watch this anime. Whether you're a part of the genre's "target audience" or not, watch this anime. It's a master-class of unflinchingly realistic character drama. It's a solid 9, very nearly 10, for me.

This is my first attempt to write a serious review. I try to apply some criticism to the animes I watch but I also highly value what I felt while watching a certain anime. That being said, I apologize in advance if my criticism isn’t sharp enough throughout this review. Also, be aware English isn’t my native language.
Story – 10/10
Nana’s story is born through the random encounter of two completely different characters, both of them named Nana. Even though they differ in so many aspects and have such opposite visions, they manage to get to know each other and their stories become intertwined. That encounterleads to the reunion of people with different lifestyles and to an amazing drama.


Art – 8/10

So, I know some people who just won’t watch Nana because of its art style. And I have to be honest here: it was one aspect that put me a bit off when I was looking for some new anime to watch. The characters do seem a bit too skinny and tall sometimes but it doesn’t really matter because once you start watching the anime, you’ll realize that there is really no better art style to portray the characters of this anime. There are actually several parts where if you just take some time, pause the anime and observe the characters in front of you, they look beautiful and, in a certain way, realistic. Also, in my opinion, the art style gives them a certain depth and it also really fits the tone and story of this anime. Summing it all up; I came to love the art style and I believe most of the people who watched this anime, did too. 


Characters – 10/10

In my honest opinion, this is where Nana truly shines. The characters are just so well developed that even if you don’t like their attitudes, you’ll end up having no choice other than to just empathize with them or at least relate to them at a certain level. There are so many animes that only focus on the main characters and basically ignore the other characters, but Nana certainly isn’t one of them. This is one of those animes where all characters have their importance and are given time to shine and make you care about them. They are well portrayed and realistic: your favorite character won’t be perfect. They will have flaws. Flaws that only make them look more human and emotionally relatable. 


Soundtrack – 10/10

Well, what can I say other than it is amazing? I’m not trying to sell anything here; it just truly is amazing. All the chosen voice actors do their job right and both singers chosen for Nana Osaki and Reira are amazing, making every performance in the anime truly enjoyable. Comparing to other music animes I’ve seen, such as Beck or Nodame Cantabile, I don’t think there is such a big of a focus on the music-making part. The music is obviously there, but not as much as it is in the animes I’ve just mentioned. The right tune just plays at the right moment and it just hits you. It hits you and you realize you’ve stumbled upon a masterpiece. 



Overall – 10/10

I’ve watched Nana two times so far and I can say that both times I felt the exact same way: fascinated. The characters and music just pull you in. The drama is somewhat intense but not in a way that will bother you; on the contrary. I recommend this to all those interested in going on a so-called “feels trip” and who are fans of the drama genre and want a story where characters actually matter. Whether you’re a huge music fan or not, won’t really affect your enjoyment of this anime; as I said, the OST is amazing and it will just do its job at the right moment. Enjoy the journey.

"Nana" will seem unusual to many anime viewers. It's a shoujo and although it may have been written with women viewers in mind, I'm a guy and found it enjoyable enough as a drama. Not many anime tropes are present here, and that's a great thing, it's almost like a western-style drama trying to realistically depict the dramatic lives of a cast of cool characters.

I've never seen characters like that in an anime, they might not be edgy by western standards but it's cool to see characters ina realistic drama who are way out of the norm for Japanese people. The other Nana might initially seem to be a shoujo cliche - a straight-laced average girl who the female viewer can identify with - but she is quirky and imperfect, and goes through some real drama that doesn't pay lip service to the way that the unrealistic standards for how a woman is "supposed" to be (but few actually are).


There is a pretty expansive cast of characters including two full bands - one established, one looking for their big break. All of the characters have personalities and are multi-dimensional, which definitely adds to the story as you actually care about these crazy kids.


The music was a mixed bag for me, some of the background music was excellent and the band's songs were decent, but they were so repetitive. I guess that's just to be expected though, it's hard to have that much great original music.


I found the ending to be unsatisfying. It wasn't awful, but I didn't really feel like it was a fulfilling finish to all of that buildup. This was probably due to the manga author having had to stop putting out new content due to an unfortunate illness.


I highly recommend this anime to anyone who likes anime dramas but is tired of the whole harem/high school drama thing. Even though some of them are quite good, they are doing the same basic thing. Don't let the shoujo label scare you off, this is really just a good drama.

I am a 17 year old, metal-loving, video-game-nerd dude. I am seemingly way off to the wrong side of 'Nana''s demographic spectrum. It seemed necessary to state all of this before throwing my opinion at you all as your mileage may vary drastically depending on your age, gender, and so forth. While I do aim to be as objective as possible, take what I say with a pinch of salt and follow my recommendation in the final paragraph if you are curious about this anime. 
So why on Earth did I pick up 'Nana'? The idea of a almost-50 episode romance did seem rather intriguing,and intriguing it was. However, what some may perceptive to be it's greatest strength, seems to be it's greatest weakness.


Story~

'Nana' follows two young women in their pursuits of laughter, fun, love, and rock 'n' roll. The story is nothing particularly special, but it is enjoyable nonetheless. There are plenty of twists and turns, and the majority of the story arcs link together well and provide plenty of meat to the over-arching plot. One thing that bogs this down slightly is re-caps. 'Nana' will take no prisoners and can and will repeat segments from previous episodes almost in their entirety, but will throw something important in the mix that leaves you with no choice but to trek through previously discovered waters. It is frustrating at times and flashbacks are generally frame-by-frame pastes so you won't be discovering anything new. But on the whole, the story is enjoyable, filled to the brim with heart-warming (and potentially heart-wrenching) scenarios that should please most anime fans.


Characters~

If there was a more divisive aspect to this show than the characters, i'd ask the court say 'I'. The characters themselves are interesting enough as individuals, even if a little unoriginal. You have your leading-role klutz, Nana. You have your lead-role unimpressed hero, Nana (yes, they share the same name. See what they did with the title? Ayyyyy). Secondary characters are fairly straightforward and don't have much going for them in terms of differentiating. Most are fairly jaded, with a couple showing a more idiotic side at times. The problem with the characters is character relationships. The relationships in 'Nana' are a level of realism that doesn't suit the medium of anime as well as one might hope. When you strip it down, 'Nana' is a B-grade romance movie presented in episodic anime format. While some may cry that the relationships are deep and allow for strong character building (which they most definitely do), the contrast with anime tropes and dramatic elongations of simple or even trivial scenarios causes an awkward fatigue. The series seems to drag on more than it should when you realise just how little has happened over the course of the first 20 episodes. The pacing of the show is brought down significantly by character relationships as the anime forces you to watch every reaction, every individual flashback. There is no room for intrigue. You know what is going to happen from a mile away, even if it isn't always the best (or most efficient) way to progress the storyline.


Art and sound~

The art deserves some praise as the character animations are brilliant. They took some getting used to (different facial proportions to typical anime, extremely skinny and tall characters), but watching individuals during conversations is one of the highlights of the show. Whenever two or more people are on the screen, you are in for a treat as conversations are as energetic in a visual sense as they are in audio. Characters are detailed and environments look good when they need to. Some backgrounds are a little too simple when compared to scenes involving concerts or restaurants, but you will likely be too glued on the wonderful voice acting and facial animations to notice. Speaking of which (segway pun intended), the voice acting is a marvel for the most part. Nana and Nana are brilliantly portrayed, and the majority of secondary characters are fun to behold; even if the general attitude of the secondary characters 70% of the time is some form of diluted cynicism. The music is enjoyable, and some of the punk tracks are quite a fun time if you don't mind the absurd lyrics Japan love to spew out.


Overall~

This show is not and never was intended for a person such as myself, yet I still found plenty to enjoy about it. Constant backtracking, realistic relationship approaches, and borderline-monotonous cynicism did bring down the overall 'enjoyment' of the show, but the emotional forces and main leading ladies did provide a fun time. The story is a tad too predictable for the most part and could easily be ripped off of a multitude of live-action films. But that doesn't stop this anime from being worth a look. The first 3 episodes should be more than enough for you to make your own judgement as to whether or not it is your cup of tea, but I would recommend you watch at least that much (do it!). This show aims for the feels, but leaves enough breathing space for enticing dialogue and some good laughs.

Most romance anime are made with the intention of portraying how a perfect relationship would be with character personalities that are just not possible in real life. This anime does exactly the opposite of that. In Nana, you are shown the flaws of every character and shows how real life is not as pretty and perfect as we expect it. You can look at the animated characters and realize that they could very well be someone in real in life, someone you have met, or even you. 
We like to dream and imagine how our ideal life would be only to realize that things change,we make mistakes, and life doesn't always take us to where we initially wanted.  This anime is basically an animated portrayal of the imperfect life of imperfect people and how their actions, mistakes, and regrets, take them to where they are.

NANA is a wonderful story; it's so realistic you can easily imagine yourself in the characters' shoes, you can identify with one or several of the characters, because the things happening in this anime, are realistic - these things happen to everyone during their lifetime.
  Sometimes you'll find yourselfso frustrated you literally want to throw your TV/computer out the window. Sometimes you're so happy for the characters that you laugh to yourself. Sometimes, you feel their sadness, and you feel your own heart aching. Such is the power of NANA.\n\n

I went into Nana expecting a typical shoujo and was instead blown away by the mature and realistic portrayal of adult life, most of all love and relationships.  It is a heart-wrenching and emotional show. It left a permanent mark on my heart and I believe it’s in a league of its own in terms of shoujo. 
The show depicts what people will do out of loneliness and an attempt to feel less empty. The characters are complex and flawed. They act painfully human- they say the wrong thing or act the wrong way, and they have to manage the consequences of their choices.They have self-destructive and unhealthy tendencies, which makes it difficult for them to be happy. 


The nature of desire is unfulfilling. Achieving your dreams won’t necessarily make you happy. Relationships and feelings are tenuous and easily crumble. Loving someone so much that you’d die with them isn’t incredibly romantic, rather it’s scary and unhealthy. 


They live in a harsh reality, not a sparkly fairy tale. Nana Komatsu is your standard shoujo protagonist. She’s bubbly, optimistic, kind-hearted, cries easily, and naïve. This show depicts how a character like this would fare in the real world, where she would be easily taken advantage of and tricked by men. The other protagonist, Nana Osaki, starts out as a tough and confident heroine but her unstable and fragile nature is gradually revealed.

“The dreams we are chasing and the reality that is chasing us are always parallel.  They never meet.”
I still remember clearly the first time my perception of anime crossed over from childish, adrenaline-driven fascination to a full-blown obsession that even then I knew already would form an integral part of my life for a long time to come.  It was when I first watched Elfen Lied: more specifically, seeing alternating episodes of dumbfounded boob groping, incestual and sadomasochistic innuendo, and mass slaughter juxtaposed over an overall atmosphere of emotional fragility that, despite its often downright kitsch clumsiness in retrospect, truly made an impactupon my often turbulent emotional state at the time.  It was the first time that I truly realized that anime could be used as a medium for more than just the adrenaline-driven beatdown fests or fantastical escapes into dreamland that appealed to me so much as a child.  Especially given its idealistic, symbolic molds of humanity that seemed to dramatically bring out the emotional core of one’s being to the artistic surface, I suddenly realized that anime could be a highly compelling, and for me at the time perhaps the only compelling, form with which to portray the powerful sentiments that touched and connected different individuals.  


Needless to say, this triggered a long period of exploration, and I combed through countless slice-of-life, romantic drama, and tongue-in-cheek harem shows looking to capture that same powerful essence that had initially left me in wonder, discovering many classic series that I still treasure dearly to this day.  However, as the backlog of completed shows piled behind me and the same predictable character archetypes and –dere derivations appeared time and time again as lethargic substitutes for true character depth, I naturally grew more jaded.  It’s not to say that a series suddenly had to be completely original to evoke enjoyability, or that I couldn’t from a subcultural perspective appreciate the “language” that anime used to call to its more hardened devotees, yet that obsessive, soul-consuming sense of awe that in the past had gripped me when encountering a truly mind-blowing tale only grew scarcer and scarcer in frequency. Going through a new show had simply become far too routine and workmanlike of an affair when I felt that everything I could have seen in it I had already seen in the past, and better. 



“Don’t just give up. Life is about getting knocked down over and over, but still getting up each time. If you keep getting up, you win.”


How was it then that Nana conflagrated my blood as easily as a river after an oil spill, causing me to blow through 47 episodes at speeds exceeding that of some of the most hook-laden Shonen series?  For starters, Nana pulls no punches when it comes to fleshing out a cast of believable, imperfect, and painfully human characters that stumble over the mess of their own weaknesses time and time again, and every time they fell, you were there bleeding alongside with them.  Indeed, the mistakes that each of the characters make, many of them blindingly obvious yet all too human, serve to endear the viewer to the characters’ stories.  For me at least, the ability to attach the viewer to the characters to the extent where the lines between perceptions of fiction and reality became blurred saturated every second of the show with raw emotion.  This was only able to be accomplished because, regardless of the hyperbolized drama, the characters in Nana and their lives were all too real and all too relatable to the mundane.  I could see more than one starry-eyed, naïve, and painfully clueless girl I had known in my life in the character of Nana K, and have seen my fair share of fragile, dependent souls hiding behind their cold walls of emotional stoicism (Nana O), pure-hearted nice guys lacking the maturity and perceptiveness to carry out their ideals (Nobu), and self-proclaimed assholes that avoided genuine, heartfelt emotional attachment as a way of coping with their sad, insecure life experiences (Takumi and Shin).  Watching Nana thus felt akin to gaining a near-omniscient insight into the lives of real, multifaceted individuals unbound by literary clichés, especially the parts of themselves most people prefer not to reveal to any but those closest to them. The show in essence achieved a level of insight into human nature that caused the everyday to subsume itself into the transcendental through an excess of detail, much like in classic Russian literature.


In many ways, perhaps partly by virtue of its Josei subgenre (a subcategory of anime I admit I have little experience with), Nana subverted and undermined many of the troupes I was so used to seeing in romance anime, feeling like a breath of fresh air in a dusty, stale room.  For example, the seemingly strong, independent, career-driven rocker that was Nana O, who would in a different context act as a liberated foil to a weak, maudlin female character, was gradually revealed to be, as far as I could see, the most emotionally delicate, dependent figure in the entire show.  What was so beautiful about the manner in which this was executed was how from episode to episode, the masks that Nana put around herself, many of which she herself only later realized she had, were gradually peeled away from her like the layers of an onion.  Nana O’s own growing self-awareness of her true nature is paralleled by the viewer’s changing perception of Nana O, with every human interaction casting a clearer definition upon her multidimensional character away from the initially formed “independent, rebellious female” archetype that one probably lumped her into at the beginning of the show.  This “movement” from character stereotype to someone more resembling a real-life individual given greater dramatic license occurred with almost every major character within the show.  In that sense, character development within Nana not only occurred through standard plot driven changes to the characters’ knowledge and base nature, but also a more meta- self-realizing unraveling of the characters’ base substance, something that was always there but not always apparent to see, for either the characters themselves or the viewer.  


The striking level of realistic detail given to every major character also made it hard to unequivocally love or hate any one of them, as all their actions had associated with them reasoning that one would be hard-pressed not to emphasize with to some degree.  The hackneyed adage of “walking in another’s shoes” is taken to a new level within Nana, with acts of sexual manipulation, infidelity, and hollow affection contextualized within the plot to almost, just almost, seem rational and perhaps even inevitable.  Of course, this hardly served to undermine the inherently heinous nature of such actions, but rather emphasized the ubiquity of the sentiments undergirding them within the depths of human nature, for both the seemingly well-adjusted and blatantly malformed alike.  Regardless of how one chose to judge a said character in the end, one at least saw clearly the difficult, winding road they took to reach the point in life they did.  



“Hey, Nana...people's feelings change easily...what you see is a house of cards...nothing's sure, and nothing lasts forever.”


I could go on dwelling upon the characterization for novels on end, but equal emphasis has to be put upon the message their stories serve to convey.  From one perspective, Nana can be viewed as two parallel journeys undertaken by two incredibly different girls to outrun their pasts and achieve their dreams.  All in the meanwhile, they yell across at each other from their parallel roads, eventually becoming the best of friends and both deep down seeking to jump onto the other’s path instead of simply moving in tandem.  However, they continue to dream of what lies at the end of the roads they are currently on, and thus ignore the forks on the road they can branch off into, continuing to stare only ahead into the darkness and never truly coming into contact with one another.  If this reeks of subtle hints of yuri to you, I’m not going to deny that Nana is not totally devoid of such innuendo, at the very least one-sidedly.  However, the subtle “longing” that always hangs uncomfortably in the atmosphere over interactions between the two Nanas acts more as a reflection of the girls’ perpetual dissatisfaction, a result of chasing often reactive, nebulous dreams that cause both to ignore, neglect, and indeed shatter (literally and metaphorically in the story) the relationships that they use to maintain their fragile worlds, relationships that are taken for granted up until the moments of their imperilment. Thus despite having seemingly different motivational drivers (Nana K. chases true love, while Nana O. chases something that would provide a perpetual bulwark against her fears of abandonment), the two girls only seem to find true peace and acceptance as they actually are within each other, a relationship ironically forged by an accidental encounter on a train.  The gradual development of these feelings that the two Nanas create as a haven for one another is beautiful to watch, though tragic that conscious acceptance of these sentiments comes only after their relationship almost gets destroyed. 


The conflict between idealized conceptions of love and the reality that love must come to bear with is perhaps the major plot driver in Nana.  Nana K. struggles through failed relationship after failed relationship with a menagerie of men from ranging from adulterating husbands to overly well-intentioned idiots, all while under the impression that she will find a one true love that could break all of the doubts and insecurities she has built around her.  Yet with time, she begins to come to the horrifying revelation that she had simply “fallen in love” with whatever guy happened to be around her in need at multiple respective time periods, and realizes just how replaceable men were in her fickle heart.  The reduction of the most seemingly sublime romantic emotions down to base needs for dependence begged the question of the foundation behind attachment, something that in the story was only grimly realized within Nana K.’s growing life wisdom coinciding with the desanctification of her heart.  This would ultimately result in her surrender to a (on the surface) bona-fide villain of a man that ironically proved to the man she needed to provide a shoulder she could safely prop her delicate ego upon.  


Indeed, the dark realism of Nana is nowhere more evident than in the failure of dedicated effort, genuine kindness, and pure love time and time again to reach positive conclusions, a striking contrast to standard consoling romantic narratives in anime where, in their own way, the nicest, most genuine man (usually manifested in the form of a bumbling, usually unpopular male MC that one could vicariously live through in their plot armor-clad march to victory) always won out in their own way.  The men in the series that displayed such characteristics all ended up inevitably lacking in other areas that unfortunately their love and devotion could not compensate for, whether it be decisiveness, maturity, or resilience in the face of adversity.  This resulted in unconsummated relationships that could not hold up against the constraints of circumstance, belying that the arena love had to contend in was a cold reality where it took far more than simply the authenticity of one’s feelings to achieve a happy ending.  On all ends, the characters of Nana were exposes of the often base, self-serving drivers behind relationships and the tenuous ground on which they rested.  Even the apparently “destined” relationship between Nana O. and Ren is left cold, abandoned and unfulfilled, much like Nana O. herself in her childhood, in the face of career ambitions and personal insecurities, insecurities that would eventually lead to the raw love between the two transforming into a complete liability.  The cynicism of the series serves not as a final indictment of the institution of love itself as a failed ideal, however, as much as a recognition that it is an emotion as complex, varied, and imperfect as the imperfect mortals that will forever continue to suffer for it by their very nature as solitary, sentient beings seeking wholeness in that which lies outside of the constraints of the isolated self. 



“I’ve always thought that life was about standing your ground, no matter how strong the current was. But going with the flow isn’t so bad after all, as long as it takes you forward.”


Perhaps for me, Nana was the right show at the right place at the right time in my life, a show that broke through the layers of jaded apathy I had built up over the years with its absolute refusal to compromise the integrity of its interactions to what for me had become hackneyed convention.  The role of music within the plot itself, in the form of the professional rivalry and personal attachments between the bands Blast! and Trapnest, only serves to aesthetically enhance the impact of the music itself (not too shabby I must say) on the viewer.  The artwork, embodied by long, glittering eyelashes, lanky, almost emaciated frames, and vibrant yet chillingly faded coloration, would certainly be an acquired taste for many, but serves perfectly through its attention to detail in visually representing every single emotion that passes through the hearts of the characters. The beauty of the execution brings the nuanced realism that underpins Nana’s appeal into a realm of hyperbolized exaggeration, where the repeated destruction of the cliché itself at the hands of the characters turns them into a new pantheon of ideological representation. I suppose the supreme irony is that the full essence of reality, in its all of its uncomfortable glory, could be so appropriately represented by fictionally, drawn characters in such a visually appealing waltz.  Not a single second did pass however, that I was not fully ensorcelled. Now if only they would adapt the rest of the manga, if it ever finishes.

Nana... It was a long journey. 
First, I'd like to say that I'm a fan of stories with drama in relationships and drama in common. Also, I like stories with plot, so why did I only now start it...? 
Nana is the story about life and the main idea of this story is love. Love between people. How they meet each other, how they love each other and how they break up with each other. Some do it because they find a better person, some – because feelings have already not the same as it was in the beginning, and some people have to doit because they love.


But, in the first place, this story about love between girls, between girl friends. How they meet each other one snowy day, by chance. 


They had never met before, they have different appearance and character – one of them is intrusive girl just like puppy that always ready to chat with her the whole life long, and the other one is like alone quite rose in garden, listening to everything puppy said. Different at all, and having nothing common, but name, they fall in love at first sight.


So, why I like ‘Nana’? Well, like I said before, I like drama and plot stories. For me, this story also was full of emotions and experience.  In first time when I only started Nana, I didn’t believe in it, because I didn’t fancy how everything will be like people were saying about it, but, with time, tension gets higher, and I didn't care about anything, I just cried over Nana’s story, and then over the further plot actions. Then, I’m imbued of both Nanas’ stories and grieve over them. I wanted a happy end for both of girls.


It is also worth mentioning a touching openings and endings. They started with aggressive, but romantic ‘rose’ and stopped with expressive ‘a little pain’; they continued with great ‘Wish’, and ended with painful and very beautiful ‘Kuroi Namida’.


The thing I don't like about 'Nana' is how characters easy lost control of their emotions in the begining. It was just stupid and... unreal, huh. 


And art. I don't care about graphics, but it's quiet unwonted when you just started watch it.

This is not your typical shoujo/slice of life. This is actually a realistic representation of people and their flaws. I find it to be deep and it really makes you examine the way life is and the way people are. 
Story: 9/10 
I looooove this anime. A lot. The reason it's not a 10, is because it's very drama based, and moves forward in a slow, emotional way, with no obvious end in sight. But in that same way, I find it very realistic, because it's not chasing a happy ending like most shoujo do. The same thing that makes it great, is also it'sdownfall. I also love the narrations in the beginning before the theme song- they often offered great insight to Hachiko's thinking. The story here really revolves around her mostly, even though Nana is a huge part of it, I always felt as though Hachiko was the main focus, probably because she has the more relatable and realistic problems out of the two. 


Art: 8/10 

I like the art on this one, although the characters definitely can be hard to get used to. But, they have quite a diverse cast, which I love. You can tell now that the art is a little dated, but it's far better than many it's age. 


Sound: 9/10 

Yes this does revolve around music quite a bit. The background music was good, nothing that I took particular notice of. The music they played was good, but it wasn't what they were focusing on here. It was more of the concept of it, and their careers. What they did play was good,  but it wasn't really the main focus. 


Character: 9/10 

At 47 episodes, it can almost seem a little repetitive- I can see many recurring themes like Hachiko's unrequited love causing her pain, her realizing and hating herself/other person for it and Nana's unwavering commitment to being herself and not letting anything stand in the way of her success with the band and being independent- of course they evolve beyond those simple principles, which is what makes this great to watch. The characters, while evolving in some aspects, do not evolve in others and that can be interesting and aggravating to watch, much like real life. The character development is amazing though, they give great insights to the way the characters think, the way they handle their emotions, and it's really compelling to watch. 


Overall: 9/10 

I really do love this anime. I think it has great themes throughout, and it is pretty fascinating to watch. Everything about it is good, but there is just something that keeps it from being great, and I think that's mainly that it has too many recurring themes for an anime this long. They struggle with the same problems on different scales throughout the whole thing. But, I also feel that's what makes this incredible realistic.

While I've only watched up to episode 23 I've read up to chapter 36 in the manga and from there I gave up. I don't think I can properly review this anime as I haven't finished it but I feel that I need to say a little something.
Nana was really addicting at first, it seemed interesting and it was a mature story. I've also seen the anime and read the manga Paradise Kiss by the same author and it had a similar vibe. I thought I'd like it. I did like it at first, but then it started going down the wrong path. I don'thave much to complain about with the art and sound, but as for the story and characters I have a lot I don't like about them. 


I really hate the main character Nana Komatsu. At first I thought I'd be able to deal with her, as she had her nice moments, but I couldn't bring myself to watch an anime when I hated the main character so much. I am willing to accept a few slip ups, but her actions in the anime are just ridiculous. 


I really liked the other characters too at first, but none of them were doing what I wanted them to do, none of them. Basically nothing was going good. Some people may enjoy drama but when it goes this far it is just boring and unbearable.


I finally couldn't take it anymore. Everything was going bad and I needed to know if something would eventually go right, and so I skipped ahead and spoiled myself. And what did I discover? That nothing got better and that it only got even more terrible and convoluted. How are any of the things that happen in this anime supposed to make the viewers happy? I at least expect some positive things to happen after all of the crap that goes down, but what do I get? More crap.


I am tired of watching entire romance anime filled with drama only to give the viewers a little bit of happiness at the last episode. (I don't even know if they give us at least that, from what I could tell from the spoilers I don't have much faith in any sort of happiness appearing.) Nana is full of drama and even if you tell me "it gets better" there is no way I am going to wade through all of this crap to get to the better parts. I'm just not that patient, I have better things to do with my time.


Remember, this review is from someone who did not finish the anime or the manga. I am just telling you what I can see from where I'm standing. Just know that this anime isn't going to be a fun ride if you don't like dealing with so much drama.

Imagine if one day, you meet someone with your name and even though you two are polar opposites, you two couldn’t be any similar. That is basically one of the major plot points of this anime that I am going to review- and I must admit that’s really interesting.
So, our story is about two girls with the same name as I mentioned earlier and they both are blessed with the name ‘Nana’. First, you have got Nana Komatsu- a ditzy, hopeless romantic who wants to head out to Tokyo so that she could be with her boyfriend Shoji and her other best friends. This Nanasearches for happiness and love, but at the same time doesn’t have any particular goals and basically spends her time day dreaming like a little girl.


Then you have got Nana Osaki- my favourite Nana in case you don’t know- a badass, Goth chick who loves singing for her band Blast and someday hopes to be a professional singer. So, she too heads out to achieve her dream and get over her ex-boyfriend Ren Honjo- and I don’t blame her for that because getting over a guy that good looking ain’t easy! Nana Osaki searches for fame and success, but at the same time despite her attitude and pride- she is often portrayed as a sweet and caring individual, who is like the mother bear of the band Blast.


The two Nanas meet on a train ride and one thing leads to another and the two end up sharing an apartment with one another. After which, our real journey into their lives really begins!


Supporting characters from Nana Komatsu’s side include her boyfriend Shouji, her friends Junko and Kyoskei. And from Nana Osaki’s side we have got her band Blast which has Nobu, Yasu, Shinichi and of course Ren, who later leaves to join the band Trapnest which causes their break up.


Now, the show starts off rather slow and I dropped it after one episode. Not because it was bad per se, but Josei anime is not really my type- even though it is targeted towards the demographic I am part off. I mean, this type of anime was new for me- mainly because despite being a girl I am not a girlish person or not even  mature enough to be interest in a show like this. So, I wasn’t sure it will be suited to my taste. However, I decided to you know step outside my comfort zone and watch it- and I’m glad I did.


Nana’s pacing at the beginning can be either seen as something bad or good. That being said, the show starts off in the present- but the next seven or eight episodes takes place in both of the Nanas’ past.  And that kind of made me hesitant to watch the show again-as it slowly progressed because I just eagerly wanted to know what happens after they move in together.

I, however did enjoy the back story at the beginning.  But, the show really did delay in starting off the actual story of the two Nanas.


After that, the pacing was flawless and just nothing to really complain about- but that’s only after they were done introducing the characters after giving their lengthy back story. One thing that kept me interested in the show was its narration. It sort of had this nostalgic feeling attached to it- making it sound and also seem as if the two Nanas share a very intense and beautiful relationship. Nana Komatsu keeps reminiscing about her past when she first met Nana Osaki and she paints a beautiful picture with words by describing the events and also about her interactions and first impressions of Nana Osaki. That is something I truly admired, and narration in general can often suck but in Nana’s case it was one of its strongest points. Towards the last twenty or so episodes, Nana Osaki takes the wheel from Komatsu and instead she starts narrating which was also executed equally well.


Now, I hate to say this and I know many of you don’t want to hear this, but I had some major issues with Nana Komatsu’s character- I mean I am not saying she is a bad character but as a main lead she doesn’t necessarily live up to expectations unlike her polar opposite Nana Osaki, who is just blowing off stereotypes!


Nana Komatsu, started off as this sweet, naïve girl who is dependent on others and can’t help but fall in love with the first cute boy she meets. Now, this is a very annoying trait- but I looked past it because I am not the type to be quick to judge. However, even by the end of the series she is more or less the same person- she is still dependent on others, she is very indecisive, and just unbelievably childish at times. It’s like she hardly got any character development despite all the shit that happened to her. 


Also, there are times you feel bad for her because since this is a drama- everything isn’t sunshine and lollipops for her- but I feel like she never learns from her past experiences and keeps on making the same stupid mistakes over and over again. Her character is a good comic relief character, but as a main female protagonist she is just a failure at being that. I mean, if you can learn anything from her character, is that you shouldn’t be an idiot and keep going back instead of moving forward. Nana keeps talking about how she is aware of the fact, that she is stupid, but she never seems to do anything about it. And I think that’s worse than being a naïve, dependent and hopeless romantic girl. 


The worst thing about her character is her indecisiveness. She doesn’t know who she is in love with or what she wants and just jumps from guy to other just to make things easier for her, especially towards the end which just brought her character down by several notches, which is sad because after fifteen or so episodes I thought she had the potential of being as great as Osaki.Nana Komatsu is a terrible role model for young girls, but yet for some reason I did enjoy her character because she did have some funny moments, none the less. I’ll give her props for that at least!


Now, Nana Osaki is one character I truly felt so sorry for. Her life was worse than Komatsu’s but yet she manages to be strong, independent and cool. You want to root for her type of character and see her succeed every step of the way. Now given the type of environment she was raised in and the way people generally perceive her, Nana Osaki could have come out as a bitch! 

No, like seriously think about it, it’s usually people with such difficult lives who always end up being bitter. However, even though Nana Osaki seems that way, she doesn’t give off that vibe. From the moment, I first saw Nana Osaki and the way she acted, despite her sarcastic and couldn’t care less attitude- she was still a kind hearted and sweet person with a heart made out of gold. She might be punk, but at the end of the day she doesn’t let that label define her. And the development she also got throughout the series was amazing. I wish that the show gave her just as much importance and screen time they gave the other Nana.


Wow, I am losing my bananas saying Nana all the time. Wait, what? Moving on…


As for the supporting cast, some are fleshed out properly and contribute to Nana’s story just as our two titular characters do. However, some of them are still shrouded in mystery even towards the end of the show and you want to know more about them. The supporting characters in my opinion are given decent amounts of screen time and most of them seem to have made some sort of impact on the two Nanas.


The animation of Nana features very tall, skeleton like characters that is reminds me of Clamp’s designs for Code Geass. The characters are very well designed, making them look very detailed and not to mention very fashionable. The artstyle of Nana already gives us the feeling that this is going to be a Josei anime before the story can get the chance to unfold to the audience. It despite being about seven to eight years old still looks top notch and has this sort of elegance and chic vibe to it that I can’t really explain that well. In case you don’t understand what I mean by all of this, I am simply trying to say that this show’s animation is awesome!


As for the opening songs there are three but it’s only the first one that really stands out the most and is also one of my favourite anime openings of all time. It suits the show so perfectly, and not mention it manages to narrate both the Nana’s struggles in lives.


 Now, for Nana, when watching the show I think the dub is better, mainly because the two actresses voicing the two Nanas do a great job of bringing their characters to life. I especially enjoy the performance of Rebecca Shoichet who voices Nana Osaki making her sound badass and sincere which is an amazing accomplishment on her part.


This show had the potential of being a shoujo ai, heck it was very close to becoming one. Not that I would have minded if this went that direction, but I am glad at the end of the day these two just remained friends. Also, the show does a good job of establishing a bond between these two which makes the show all the more great. The banter between the two is hilarious and the moments the two share can range from being heartbreaking to being downright hilarious. 


The last few episodes of Nana felt rushed in my opinion as they tried to wrap everything up very messily. It just didn’t work in my opinion and still by the end, a plethora of questions were left unanswered about certain characters. Many consider it a disappointment, and I can’t help but agree with them.  

The plot of this show might not be anything as exciting as something filled with aliens, time travelers and espers, hence this anime is not necessarily for everyone.


This show isn’t your average high school lovey dovey melodramatic romance anime, but is actually very realistic in the sense that it actually tells the story of two young women and their personal struggles in the world which many women can relate and or identify themselves with. 


So, if you’re a teenage boy that enjoys explosions, guns and fight scenes, or a girl who loves sparkly backgrounds, teenage romance and bishounen catboys then you are not going to like this show. However, if you are willing to step outside your comfort zone and give this show a chance then maybe you’ll like it. I am not saying you will, but you might!


I am going to award Nana with an 8 and say that is definitely WORTH THE WATCH. I would give it a higher score if it wasn't for it's anti-climactic ending.


 If you want to get into Josei anime I suggest you start with Nana, it’s the perfect gateway into this particular genre. It’s a mature show with great characters, a decent plot and amazing music. I surprisingly enjoyed this show a lot, and it is also a harsh reminder that life is unfair and hard, so yeah basically a bitch!

Nana is an anime about two girls called Nana. Nana Osaki is a musician from the countryside that went to Tokyo with her band to try live from music and be a star on the city, while Nana Komatsu was an "artist" from the countryside that went to Tokyo to live with her boyfriend. Some things happen and end up like two living in the same house, the anime walks around their romantic lives, their past, the difficulties of life, among other subjects.
What i like about the anime is that they show to girls with the same name, almost the same age, the same dreamof leaving in the big city, how they deal with the pass and the present, their romance problems. They show how to girl can be so alike but so different from each other.


I can't say much more about it with given spoilers, so if you like romance and drama, give a try to Nana.


You may be wary of my numerical evaluation because it is one of my favorite animes, however the evaluation was made based on my tastes and not the criteria of each of the readers.


Story: 10 out of 10


Nana's story is very well written and quite complete. The story is made from one of the main characters reminiscent of how they met, how their two worlds came together, their problems, how they supported each other. All the events of the story are well connected, there are no characters that disappear or reappear miraculously, all of which have some relevance at a certain point in the story.


Art: 10 out of 10


This is one of those points where there may be discord, personally I like the art type and I think it fits the story very well. Despite that hardcore metal aspect, Nana has an excellent voice, the speed of the song fits very well with the speed of the story and the lyrics of the song end up emphasizing the character's feelings.


Character: 10 out of 10


One of the most important aspects, all the characters are developed in a way that concerns the story,there are no developments that lead to the abandonment of the main story and there are no characters that are not developed, all the characters are exploited but only in the aspects that have revelation to the story.


Enjoyment: 10 out of 10


I enjoyed the story, the music, the art, everything.


Overall: 10 out of 10


Remember the evaluation was made based on my tastes and not the criteria of each of the readers.

" I don't want the strength of our bonds to be tested by some communication device " NANA .
It's been some time since I've felt so happy and sad cause of an anime and tbh I kinda wonder if it has ever been this deep .

Since you can read the synopsis I will skip the brief explanation and getto the point which is that it has a really engaging and entertaining story . I don't easily look down on people based on what they are, or what they do. It's the attitude and the way of thinking that I rather look up to. Whether they do good things or bad things, I think it's only a matter of context (the percieved "good/bad things" itself may differ each person, depending on their principal values). Maybe we end up choosing the same path if we were in his/her condition. Maybe we fall into a much darker pit. No one knows. But the two things I mentioned, it's what differentiate the true, "good" person from the other.
In my life of watchinganime, I've never seen anything as comforting as it is depressing and as real as watching NANA. The feeling of love, anger, betrayal, pride, fear, sympathy and regret I received from learning both the lead characters, living the "determining stage of life" that is the transition into adulthood, gave me chills and warmth throughout the course of the series.


NANA is a 2006 anime adapted from a manga written and illustrated by Ai Yazawa. It tells about the chance encounter of Nana Komatsu and Nana Osaki, later about their friendship and each of their own lives. The two met on a fateful night in a bullet train to Tokyo, and sat next to each other. Hachi (lets just call the first girl this) came to Tokyo to finally meet her boyfriend, Shoji, though honestly it seems like she came just to find "love" in general. Nana on the other hand came to Tokyo to become a rock star. Both have same name, same age, same destination, and same motive: to start a new life.


Nana Komatsu, an air-headed girl from a small town up in northern Japan (I guess Tohoku region? It's never explicitly stated) who finds "love" as much as people do their laundry. I hate this girl. Ya, she's got the appeal, but blatantly speaking she really gave me frustration almost every 2-3 episodes, if not every episode, for all her "wishy washy" attitude when deciding about anything and still regret it after. I honestly couldn't care less about her desire for love, "doing it" every time she thinks she's found "the guy"; but the repetitive mistakes she made after finding out "it wasn't really what she wanted" really ticks me off.


Then there's Nana Osaki, also from a small town in northern Japan, who wanted to become a rock star. Back home she already made a name for herself together with her band called the Black Stones, until one of the members decided to leave and join a soon-to-be popular band in Tokyo. This caused conflict and later hiatus, and was devastating for the band at first. But Nana quickly stood up and continued to chase her dream.


Hachi and Nana coincidentally met again when they were looking for a place to live in Tokyo, and, as fate would have it, decided to live together (Yes, Hachi ultimately didn't live with Shoji. Say this was the first drama of many). The two bear different personalities, yet it's what made them so close. I like how their apartment became the "connecting hub" of different people and friends, and how they became a host of many moments and stories, past and present (and future), all mashed in one room. Outside, they have their own different lives, doing different things, interacting with different people. But when they get home, it's their world together. It's fate--one of the things that made me like this series.


Every season never cease to astound me, like riding a never-ending roller coaster. One time it made me so frantic I felt like flipping a table. And the fact that it was left hanging upset me even more. But if it were to resemble life, it would never have a "true ending", it'd keep moving and changing every time as long as you live. It's 47 episodes long, but I highly recommend people watching 😊

The name of the Demon King recurs often in Nana, and it is often used as comedic relief when something unfortunate or inconvenient happens to one of the characters. However, the reference to the demon king may hold a more dramatic metaphor for the initiated, as Ai Yazawa weaves a story of loss, pain, music, and, most importantly, love.
Story: 8/10
Unlike other stories, Nana's plotline is distinct from the development of its characters. While the two are affecting each other in substantial ways, the story seemingly moves forward with its own volition, not getting dragged down by the personal burdens of the characters within its weftand weave. This is sometimes a good thing, as the story moves, the past gets buried and festers into emotionless apathy or a deep scar, which further develops the character later on. However, the bad side is that the story manages to feel out-of-pace at times, and even glossing over details that were such an important and dramatic section of the previous episodes. In the later half of the show, Hachi's problems are paddled into the background as Nana takes center stage as narrator, and character conflicts begin to both drive the story and fragment the story. Various conflicts taking place at the exact same time sometimes made the later episodes feel jumbled and splintered, leaving a jarring sense of disconnect that takes one out of the story and go, "that didn't make much sense." Of course, with a story so heavily based on emotion, logic doesn't work its way into the plotline very often, but that leads to clashing between subplotlines that feel poorly designed.


Art: 7/10

Although calling the characters in Nana stick figures isn't exactly accurate, it does say a great deal about the design of the characters relative to other series produced in the same season. The other shoujo drama that aired the same season, Ouran High School Host Club, also suffered from this slightly, but managed to keep the characters well-proportioned underneath their school uniforms and casual wear. Nana, on the other hand, stylized everyone as these skin-over-bones humans who can't seem to put on weight. Only when winter clothes are introduced that the characters get a little more substance to their figure. Overall, however, animation quality was still good, free from any notable error occurring within the scenes. Madhouse did well in its editing for this show.


Sound: 9/10

For a show that focuses so much on the music industry as a whole, the sound is much more important here, relatively speaking. Both Anna Tsuchiya and OLIVIA did wonderful jobs as Nana Osaki and Reira Serizawa in the opening and closing songs. Beautiful piano melodies evoked sadness at dramatic scenes, while the punkish theme of the show came through when either BLAST or Trapnest was put in center stage. The singular gripe that can be said about the sound is that the natural singing voices of Romi Park and Aya Hirano drew a considerable difference in sound for both of the singers, leading to a certain degree of disconnect for the viewer.


Character: 10/10

As with all stories, character development is a huge part of a show, and Nana is absolutely no exception. Hell, most of the show is ABOUT character development, and it is absolutely wonderful to see that directors and producers left most of Ai Yazawa's story intact and preferred a narrative style to portray Nana instead of pure acting. To see both Nanas struggle through the memories of their past and either leave behind old ghosts or be continuously haunted by them throughout the show makes the story almost haunting, and definitely capable of drawing a viewer to stay connected to the story, even when other elements fall short. The other members of BLAST also got fully fleshed out backstories, with motivations that are clear to opaque, since the story is told through the eyes of either Nana K. or Nana O. Nobu, for example, is very much like Hachi in terms of easygoing love, but is passionate and pure to the point of being very simple to figure out motivations, though his actions aren't exactly as predictable. Meanwhile, Yasu stands as a piece of slate in comparison, as not even Nana O., his own bandmate, manages to figure out what exactly drives his actions at times, and the viewer is given few glimpses into his mind during his private conversations with other characters. Trapnest also has terrifically designed characters, with Naoki being a comedic relief when the story emerges from a heavy arc. Delving into any of the characters in a spoiler, however, but that should give an indication that the story is thoroughly developed and intricately weaved with the backstories and, sometimes conflicting, motivation of each character.


Overall: 9/10

Nana is not a perfect show by any means. Sometimes, its errors and faults glare through in pretty substantial ways, and takes a viewer out of the carefully crafted world of Tokyo back into real life. And yet, Nana seeks to mirror real life, in the way that not everything ends up happy, and sacrifices isn't just something meant for the underprivileged and poor. Romance isn't the happy-go-lucky emotional rollercoaster that other shows may portray it as, and Nana does a wonderful relating romance, whether it be love, friendship, or a passion for music, to how not everyone gets what they want in the end, and how not everyone can be merely read like the words they are born from.

"Nee Nana.." 
Only two words but it brings so much emotions.. I still feel uncomfortable after hearing it and I have that bittersweet feeling running down the spine.
I actually was reluctant to watch this anime.
I tried reading the manga once before and I had a hard time dealing with the art (and I know it's dumb because art shouldn't matter if there's a good story behind it..). So I just stopped reading it. I might be weird or something but I'm the kind of person who loves crying in front of a sad anime. So... Four years after that I was talking with a goodfriend of mine asking her if she had any good recommendation for heart-breaking animes, and she told me "Watch Nana". I decided to give it a try...


Art: 6/10

So what struck me the most was of course the art. Since it was one of the reason I stopped reading the manga it was kinda hard to go back at it. I wasn't a fan of these long legs, tall and thin characters. It was way too different from what I was used to watch.

In the meantime I grew up and decided to just ignore these few things I didn't like and focus on the other aspects of the anime. 


Story: 8/10

I guess you can read the synopsis by yourself, the story itself was good. I don't know what to say about it. It was a "slice of life" type where you follow the life of two girls. Don't kill me for what I'm going to say but there's nothing that exciting except the fact that one of them is a singer for a punk band. There's the usual friendship and love drama. Saying it this way might be a little bit depreciating but the way it is written and depicted through the entire anime is so damn good. I've never watched a series that had such a serious tone/mood and that was being so poetic (Yes I'm talking here about the parts at the beginning or ending of each episode with the famous "Nee.. Nana..." and yes this were my favorite moments)


Characters: 10/10

The characters are perfect, every single one of them has a background story, no one was left behind. The two main characters are sooo different and yet they suit each other so much. I sincerely could say that even though both Nana are the main characters, the other characters are as much important as them. They aren't here just to "fill" episodes with side stories and then disappear, they are intertwined with each other in specific relationships and that shows how much effort has been put in each character to make it unique.


Sound: 10/10

I mean c'mon, I have no idea what people think about the soundtrack but can you really not enjoy it? I was more a fan of Trapnest songs (which are pretty calm compared to Black Stones). 

But there's definitely one song that surpassed all of them and it's "Kuroi Namida" . I still remember the last word of the last episode with this song in the background and... dem feels... ;___;


Enjoyment: 10/10

I literally watched this anime in one week, every evening I watched a much as I could before sleeping and I did not regret. I cried way too much (so if you feel a bit depressed, please wait a little before watching this haha, might not be good for your poor little heart).


Overall: 10/10 

I don't really know how to convince you it's really hard to express my feelings towards Nana but it's definitely one of this anime that you'll remember. 

If you have some time to spare.. 47 episodes isn't that long and I promise you'll really enjoy it.

Where would anime be without Studio Madhouse? At least during this era of anime this particular studio was seemingly all over the place in genres, but also quality. Luckily, this incredibly popular manga, Nana, had an amazing source material to go straight off of along with director Morio Asaka. He has a history of more “childish” romance anime like Chobits and Cardcaptor Sakura, but also had experience in storyboard with more mature shows like Monster and Black Lagoon. Some questions that would arise during development were could the studio create a quality show, stay true to the mature source material, and an accurate portrayal ofcharacter relationships?


“Do you remember the first time we met?” Really, this opening statement sets the tone and introduces the mood going forward. These two aspects are done extremely well in Nana. Word choices in dialogue between characters is done in a way where even the minutest details has impact in the present and future for the show. Emotion then, of course, plays an even greater role for character development from episode to episode just like a real person would. This world in Nana creates something that fans and the like can then relate to these characters on a personal level.


Nana is about two women with the same name but are two different people with different directions in life. Unlike the usual romance anime about love, lost, and ultimately tropes, Nana is more like an afternoon Soap Opera. The show follows the two Nana girls and the group that is around them. It starts off a bit melancholy and even comedic at times, but then develops as would someone’s real life where the characters experience difficult relationship turns, break ups, and creating personal bonds. It is within these moments that a slow build is done ultimately resulting in a climatic “personal” moment. Therefore, the first half of the 47 episodes focus on these developments to create some of the most heart wrenching moments to experience in anime. This might be some of the most divers, relatable, and believable cast since previous shows such as the romance of Honey and Clover and the music anime of Beck.


Now, the animation is a consistent high quality such as everything being animated and smooth during live band performances. The music being fantastic then goes without saying. However, emotional moments are hurt by trivial and bland voice acting throughout the show. Other aspects that lowers Nana is the consistent censorship the show went through cutting out drug use making character developments not understandable during the anime and the worst is the original ending due to the manga being unfinished. Not saying the ending is bad, but so many questions and what happened to the characters are unknown unless the manga is read. 


Life does go on and Nana portrays this in a believable way. This is an emotional roller coaster that is near perfection. A high recommend.
